Bryan_Sutton:
{{short description|American musician (born 1973)}} {{For|those of a similar name|Brian Sutton (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Bryan Sutton | image = File:Bela Fleck concert for My Bluegrass Heart 2, April 12 2022.jpg | caption = Sutton (second from right) playing guitar in 2022, in support of [[Bela Fleck]]'s album [[My Bluegrass Heart]]. | image_size = | birth_place = [[Asheville, North Carolina]], U.S. | birth_date = 1973 | origin = United States | instrument = [[Guitar]]
[[Banjo]]
[[Mandolin]] | genre = [[Country music|Country]], [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]] | occupation = [[Musician]] | years_active = 1997–present | label = [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass)|Sugar Hill]] | associated_acts = [[Ricky Skaggs]] and [[Kentucky Thunder]], [[Hot Rize]] | website = {{URL|www.bryansutton.com}} }} '''James Bryan Sutton'''{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/890390531 |title=BIG ISLAND HORNPIPE |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=April 26, 2023}} is an American [[musician]]. Primarily known as a [[flatpicking]] [[Steel-string guitar|acoustic guitar]] player, Sutton also plays [[mandolin]], [[banjo]], [[ukulele]], and [[electric guitar]]. He also sings and writes songs. ==Biography== ===Early career=== Sutton's grandfather and father were regionally recognized fiddlers, and Sutton grew up playing in the family band, the Pisgah Pickers. In 1991, he played guitar for [[Karen Peck and New River]], a gospel group. In 1993, he moved to [[Nashville]].{{cite web|url=http://porterbriggs.com/bluegrass-and-balsam-appalachias-own-bryan-sutton/|title=Bluegrass and Balsam: Appalachia's Own Bryan Sutton|work=PorterBriggs.com|access-date=June 14, 2017|author=Emily Glaser|archive-date=August 9, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160809181344/http://porterbriggs.com/bluegrass-and-balsam-appalachias-own-bryan-sutton/|url-status=dead}}{{cite news|last1=Stone|first1=Steven|title=Bryan Sutton: Into His Own|url=http://www.vintageguitar.com/21188/bryan-sutton-2/|access-date=June 14, 2017|work=Vintage Guitar Magazine|date=December 1, 2014}} ===Ricky Skaggs=== Sutton first came to prominence in 1997 as lead guitarist in [[Ricky Skaggs]]' band [[Kentucky Thunder]] when Skaggs returned to [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]]. Sutton eventually left the band to focus on session work.{{cite news|last1=Netherland|first1=Tom|title=Guitar phenomenon Bryan Sutton looks to next challenge|url=http://www.heraldcourier.com/community/guitar-phenomenon-bryan-sutton-looks-to-next-challenge/article_f5bee2e4-feb0-11e6-a288-57447037f9c8.html|access-date=June 14, 2017|work=Bristol Herald-Courier|date=March 1, 2017}} ===Hot Rize=== [[File:Hot Rize-by Eric Frommer.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.4|Hot Rize in 2004: [[Pete Wernick]], [[eTown|Nick Forster]], [[Tim O'Brien (musician)|Tim O'Brien]], Bryan Sutton]] Bryan was asked to join the bluegrass quartet [[Hot Rize]] in 2002. He has toured and recorded with them ever since, and has only missed one show since they re-formed.{{cite news|last1=Leslie|first1=Jimmy|title=Bryan Sutton on Hot Rize, Low End, and Fluid Flatpicking|url=http://www.guitarplayer.com/artists/1424/bryan-sutton-on-hot-rize-low-end-and-fluid-flatpicking/50787|access-date=June 14, 2017|work=Guitar Player|date=February 6, 2015|archive-date=September 7, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907120008/http://www.guitarplayer.com/artists/1424/bryan-sutton-on-hot-rize-low-end-and-fluid-flatpicking/50787|url-status=dead}} ===Session work and touring=== In addition to Skaggs and Hot Rize, Sutton has toured with the [[Dixie Chicks]], [[Jerry Douglas (musician)|Jerry Douglas]], [[Sam Bush]], [[Béla Fleck]], [[Hot Rize]], [[Chris Thile]], [[Tony Rice]] and others.{{cite web|url=http://musiccityroots.com/2014/bryan-sutton-band|title=Bryan Sutton Bans|work=Music City Roots|access-date=June 5, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170530025134/http://musiccityroots.com/2014/bryan-sutton-band|archive-date=May 30, 2017|url-status=dead}} In 2007-08, Sutton toured with [[Chris Thile]] & The How to Grow a Band, a project which later turned into the [[Punch Brothers]].{{cite news|last1=Ellis |first1=Andy|title=Bryan Sutton|url=http://www.guitarplayer.com/miscellaneous/1139/bryan-sutton/11979|access-date=June 14, 2017|work=Guitar Player|date=April 1, 2010}} Bryan is one of the most in-demand session players in Nashville, and recently produced a record for Della Mae and the Cash Cabin. His style is a unique blend of staccato mixed with powerful chromatic and melodic movements which is integrated into the more common bluegrass, blues and folk leads that are common to the genre.{{cite news|last1=Reed|first1=James|title=Della Mae puts extra pluck in its bluegrass|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2013/05/30/della-mae-put-extra-pluck-their-bluegrass/y7JuiP6EOQoka6WlY4RFcP/story.html|access-date=June 14, 2017|work=Boston Globe|date=May 30, 2013}} ===Other projects=== In June, 2011 he launched the [http://artistworks.com/guitar-lessons-bryan-sutton Online Bluegrass Guitar School with Bryan Sutton], as part of the [[ArtistWorks]] [http://academyofbluegrass.com Academy of Bluegrass].{{cite news|last1=staff writer|title=ArtistsWorks to Launch Online Bluegrass Guitar School with Bryan Sutton|url=http://www.guitarplayer.com/miscellaneous/1139/artistsworks-to-launch-online-bluegrass-guitar-school-with-bryan-sutton/13580|access-date=June 14, 2017|work=Guitar Player|date=May 26, 2011}}{{Dead link|date=October 2023 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2013, Sutton recorded the album ''Ready for the Times'' with [[T. Michael Coleman]] and [[David Holt (musician)|David Holt]]. They recorded the album as a tribute to Doc Watson.{{cite news|title=Sutton, Holt & Coleman-Ready for the Times|url=http://bluegrassmusic.com/content/2013/reviews/sutton-holt-coleman-ready-times/|access-date=August 9, 2017|work=Bluegrass Unlimited|date=October 1, 2013|archive-date=August 11, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170811061151/http://bluegrassmusic.com/content/2013/reviews/sutton-holt-coleman-ready-times/|url-status=dead}} The trio got together in 2011, and have performed frequently under the name Deep River Rising.{{cite news|last1=Gevock|first1=Nick|title=Inspired by Doc Watson, Deep River Rising trio carries on tradition|url=http://mtstandard.com/news/local/inspired-by-doc-watson-deep-river-rising-trio-carries-on/article_a65d55ee-cb0e-11e1-905b-0019bb2963f4.html|access-date=August 10, 2017|work=Montana Standard|date=July 11, 2012}} ===Recordings=== For ''Almost Live'', Sutton was joined by 17 guest musicians, including [[Béla Fleck]] (banjo), [[Jerry Douglas]] (resonator guitar), [[Russ Barenberg]] (guitar), Chris Thile (mandolin), and [[Stuart Duncan]] (fiddle). Sutton's album ''Into My Own'' featured guests [[Bill Frisell]] (guitar), [[Ronnie McCoury]] (mandolin), and [[Noam Pikelny]] (banjo). On 2016's ''The More I Learn'', Sutton continued to develop and showcase his singing and songwriting skills. The album prominently features Bryan Sutton Band members Casey Campbell (mandolin), Mike Barnett (fiddle), and Sam Grisman (bass).{{cite web|url=http://lonesomeroadreview.com/learn-bryan-sutton/|title="The More I Learn" by Bryan Sutton|work=The Lonesome Road Review|access-date=June 14, 2017|author=Donald Teplyske|archive-date=November 4, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104115301/http://lonesomeroadreview.com/learn-bryan-sutton/|url-status=dead}} ==Awards== *2000 - [[International Bluegrass Music Association|IBMA]] Guitar Player of the Year *2003 - IBMA Guitar Player of the Year *2004 - IBMA Guitar Player of the Year *2005 - IBMA Guitar Player of the Year *2006 - IBMA Guitar Player of the Year *2007 - [[Grammy Award for Best Country Instrumental Performance]] for ''Whiskey Before Breakfast'' w/ Doc Watson. The song was recorded using 3 vintage Neumann microphones and a laptop in a Colorado hotel room by Engineer Phil Harris. *2011 - IBMA Guitar Player of the Year {{cite web | title = STEVE MARTIN & THE STEEP CANYON RANGERS NAMED IBMA ENTERTAINERS OF THE YEAR | publisher = International Bluegrass Music Association | url = http://ibma.org/node/280 | access-date = 2011-12-08 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111123195640/http://ibma.org/node/280 | archive-date = 2011-11-23 }} *2013 - IBMA Guitar Player of the Year *2014 - IBMA Guitar Player of the Year *2014 - ''Into My Own'' was nominated for a Grammy in the Best Bluegrass Album category{{cite news|last1=Kopp|first1=Bill|title=Bryan Sutton on the "DNA of Bluegrass"|url=http://nodepression.com/interview/bryan-sutton-dna-bluegrass|access-date=June 14, 2017|work=No Depression|date=March 6, 2015}} *2015 - IBMA Guitar Player of the Year{{cite web|url=https://bourgeoisguitars.net/our-news/bryan-sutton-rhonda-vincent-win-at-ibma/|title=Bryan Sutton, Rhonda Vincent win at IBMA!|work=Bourgeois Guitars|access-date=June 14, 2017|archive-date=July 9, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170709000815/https://bourgeoisguitars.net/our-news/bryan-sutton-rhonda-vincent-win-at-ibma/|url-status=dead}} *2016 - IBMA Guitar Player of the Year{{cite news|last1=Lawless|first1=John|title=2016 IBMA Awards results|url=https://bluegrasstoday.com/2016-ibma-awards-results/|access-date=June 14, 2017|work=Bluegrass Today|date=September 29, 2016}} ==Gear== Bryan supports [http://bourgeoisguitars.net/ Bourgeois Guitars] and performs regularly with his own signature model, a [https://web.archive.org/web/20151003224457/http://bourgeoisguitars.net/limited-edition/bryan-sutton/ Bourgeois Bryan Sutton Limited Edition]. He also uses a Bourgeois "[http://bourgeoisguitars.net/guitars-archived/country-boy-deluxe/ Country Boy Deluxe] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151004003313/http://bourgeoisguitars.net/guitars-archived/country-boy-deluxe/ |date=2015-10-04 }}" model [[Dreadnought (guitar type)|dreadnought]], and a Bourgeois "[http://bourgeoisguitars.net/guitars-specialty-models/bk-slope-d/ Banjo Killer] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151004002819/http://bourgeoisguitars.net/guitars-specialty-models/bk-slope-d/ |date=2015-10-04 }}" slope-shouldered dreadnought, which is another model directly inspired by Bryan. He also regularly performs with a 1940 [[C.F. Martin & Co.|Martin]] D-28. ==Discography== {{Main| Bryan Sutton discography}} == References == ==External links== *[http://www.bryansutton.com/ BryanSutton.com, Official site] * {{AllMusic | id= bryan-sutton-mn0000938636 | label= Bryan Sutton}} * {{discogs artist|521911-Bryan-Sutton|Bryan Sutton}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060912005941/http://www.flatpick.com/Pages/Featured_Artist/Sutton.html Bryan Sutton Interview] *[http://artistworks.com/guitar-lessons-bryan-sutton Online Bluegrass Guitar School with Bryan Sutton] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sutton, Bryan}} [[Category:Bluegrass musicians from North Carolina]] [[Category:American country guitarists]] [[Category:American country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:Grammy Award winners]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Resonator guitarists]] [[Category:American country banjoists]] [[Category:1973 births]] [[Category:American acoustic guitarists]] [[Category:American male guitarists]] [[Category:American bluegrass mandolinists]] [[Category:Musicians from Asheville, North Carolina]] [[Category:Guitarists from North Carolina]] [[Category:American session musicians]] [[Category:20th-century American guitarists]] [[Category:21st-century American male singers]] [[Category:21st-century American singer-songwriters]] [[Category:Country musicians from North Carolina]] [[Category:21st-century American guitarists]] [[Category:Punch Brothers members]] [[Category:Hot Rize members]] [[Category:Kentucky Thunder members]] [[Category:American male singer-songwriters]] [[Category:Singer-songwriters from North Carolina]]
